original_responses.project_ideas:
I want to design good architectures that can scale and deal with complex time-series problem. Specifically, I want to combine transformers with Spiking Neural Network and work on time series problem.

Expected outcome: demonstrate that SNN can be used for Time series problem, achieving comparable performances while demonstrating energy efficiency.

original_responses.project_ideas: Strategy and speed optimization for solar car racing. I'm part of the SolarCar design team, where we race in a cross-country multi-day endurance race. We already have mathematical models to predict energy usage in different weather and terrain conditions, but we lack a sophisticated method for planning ahead. (For example, should we slow down when it is cloudy because there is less energy, or speed up because we might be able to make it through the storm and get sun on the other side). Besides weather, terrain including hills and curves is a major factor. Since we have the mathematical model for the solarcar available as well as weather and solar data from during previous year's races, I'm hoping to use reinforcement learning to create an optimized race strategy. Please let me know if you have any suggestions!

original_responses.experience: I worked on Distributed ML for IoT systems. I specifically focus on fault-tolerant and robust FL. I published a couple of papers on FL architectures and model aggeration algorithms in IEEE. I also specialized in AIML during my bachelors which included courses like deep learning, soft computing and reinforcement learning.
original_responses.problem_type: Open-ended exploration (e.g., discover new patterns, create novel applications, research questions)
original_responses.project_ideas: I wish to focus on resource constrained ML focusing on how we can train (different from TinyML's focus on inference) a model on computationally smaller devices. I am particularly interested in whether devices with heterogeneous computational capabilities can collaboratively train a model, similar to FL but without requiring identical architectures. I am also interested in whether neural network architectures can be dynamically shrunk or expanded while preserving learned knowledge, enabling adaptable training across changing resource constraints. There is a technique called neural net surgery, but it applies only for linear activation function. Developing/Exploring it's functionality on non linear activation functions will give us an understanding and might possibly lead to the development of a technique for changing a model's architecture. If we can shrink a model's architecture with same knowledge, we can compute the inference in less number of FLOPs leading to better efficiency.

original_responses.experience: My AI/ML experience has been developed mainly through research rather than a formal learning path. I have worked on topics such as semantic communication and continuity-aware modeling in 2D and 3D computer vision. Through this work, I have learned and applied relevant AI/ML techniques and the underlying algorithms needed for these research areas.
original_responses.problem_type: Open-ended exploration (e.g., discover new patterns, create novel applications, research questions)
original_responses.project_ideas: I am interested in research projects related to security in the Open Radio Access Network (O-RAN). I propose a project focused on real-time detection of rogue devices in the RAN by analysing changes in Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) measured at the base station. The main challenge is designing an algorithm that can detect such anomalies with very low latency, enabling timely protective actions. This is a critical and timely problem in modern cellular networks, and I believe this project represents a strong and impactful research idea with practical relevance to current RAN security challenges.

original_responses.experience: I have intermediate experience in machine learning, with a focus on applications in geoscience, remote sensing, and environmental systems. My background includes coursework in statistical learning and data analytics, along with extensive hands-on experience working with large spatiotemporal datasets (e.g., Satellite data, hydroclimate variables). I have applied unsupervised learning methods such as PCA, ICA and clustering for pattern discovery in deformation and hydrologic time series, as well as supervised models for prediction and attribution tasks.
original_responses.project_ideas: I am interested in ML applications for Earth system science, particularly in hydrology, land subsidence, and climate-driven hazards. My interests include time-series analysis, spatiotemporal clustering, physically informed ML, explainable AI, and data fusion between satellite observations and process-based models. I am also very open to collaborating with others, exploring new application areas, and expanding my ML skill set through projects.
